Dear Mr. Jurasek:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,

ALLEGATION:
Staff at facility performed a restraint on youth due to property destruction.
INVESTIGATION:
On 9/21/21 an Incident Report of a restraint at the facility was reviewed. The incident
report suggested Youth A was restrained because he punched a computer monitor.
The Incident Report was dated 9/19/21. It stated Youth A was in a high state of
anxiety. He was frustrated about an Incident Report that was written when he
2

assaulted his peer last week. Staff tried to have a discussion with him about the
report but he became defensive. Youth A then went to the office and demanded to
see his Incident Report. Staff told him he could not see it. He was still anxious and
asked to go outside. Staff asked him to de-escalate in his room for a few minutes
due to it being shift change. Youth A continued to demand to see his report. He was
directed to go to his room then became “irate” and punched the computer screen.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 attempted to put Youth A in a Team Control Restraint. Youth A
and the staff slipped on water that was on the floor. Due to how they all went to the
floor Youth A ended up on top of Staff 1 and began to punch staff. Staff physically
managed Youth A’s arms while on the ground. After a minute staff disengaged.
Youth A was given some space. He walked in and out of the house and eventually
ended up punching and breaking a window. He was then placed in another restraint.
The Chief Administrator (CA) was contacted via telephone on 9/21/21 and asked
about the incident. He stated he thought Youth A was restrained due to him hitting
the computer. Since it was not clear if the restraint was initiated due to property
destruction or another reason the CA was told an investigation would need to be
completed.
Youth A’s case file documentation was reviewed. He was placed at the facility
through the court. He has a calming plan that indicates he gets upset when people
yell at him, repeat directions to him, and talk to him in a disrespectful tone. Some
things that help him are music, coloring and thinking by himself. A behavior plan was
put in place after this incident. It indicated Youth A argues with staff to a point where
he is unable to stop or back down from a confrontation. To help him address this
behavior he will ask for space alone in his room, refocus for five minutes, and/or find
a work session. His treatment plan indicates he has done well at the facility, but he is
easily frustrated and at times struggles to manage his emotions. He does have a
history of aggression and violence.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility on 9/23/21. He stated that things were good
at the facility and that he has his ups and downs. He reported on Sunday he hit the
computer then broke a window. He broke the computer screen when he hit it. He
resisted staff and ended up hitting his head on the door. He stated he was mad due
to a critical that he received. The staff present were Staff 1 and Staff 2. He could not
remember how he ended up on the floor. He said he could not remember much of
anything. When he was on the ground, he picked something up to hit staff with. Him
and the staff were on the ground wrestling and other staff came over. Youth A stated
he was being a jerk when he hit the computer. He does not like people touching him
and he felt like he was being attacked and needed to fight back.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on 9/23/21. He reported Youth A was anxious
all day. Staff 1 continuously tried to talk him down. Youth A was asking about his
critical and was having a hard time accepting responsibility for why he received the
critical. At shift change he was supposed to be in his room, but he came to the office
door. Youth A had seen the critical the previous night and wanted to see it again. He
3

then asked to go outside. Staff 1 stated he was trying to get Youth A to de-escalate
without going outside. Youth A then hit the computer screen. Staff 1 immediately
went to hold Youth A. Not to restrain him but to calm him down. Youth A then fought
Staff 1 and tried to hit him. They fell to the floor due to water being on the floor
making it slippery. They were on the floor less than a minute. Youth A then got up
and walked toward the door. Staff 1 stated he tried to stop Youth A from hitting the
computer because he has seen Youth A try to hurt himself before, so he was trying
to prevent Youth A from being injured. Youth A did hurt his hand either from hitting
the computer or when he hit the window later. Staff 1 again said he was not planning
to restrain Youth A but to get him to stop and not hurt himself. He stated he was
trying to show Youth A care. When asked he stated it was supposed to be more like
a hug to drain off his emotions which is something he has done with Youth A in the
past. Staff 1 stated he did not think it would have gone the way it did had they not
slipped to the floor.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility on 9/23/21. She stated Youth A was highly
anxious. Staff 1 talked to him. Youth A was upset that his home pass was cancelled
due to him earning a critical for hitting another kid. Youth A was yelling and cussing
at the staff. He then punched the computer and knocked items off the desk. Staff 1
put Youth A in a standing hold. Youth A struggled and they went to the ground when
they slipped. She grabbed his legs, but they soon let him up. He was still aggressive.
Youth A went outside then came back into the house. Emergency procedures were
called because Youth A was still escalated. He then punched the window and was
placed in team control in the living room. His hands were injured and wrapped up.
They took him to the Emergency Room, but he did not need stitches. Staff 2
reported once Youth A is escalated there is no calming down. He was restrained for
safety reasons to prevent harm to himself and others. Youth A has in the past been
harmful to himself and others when escalated.
The video of the incident was reviewed on 9/30/21 via Zoom due to potential COVID
exposure on campus. Manager 1 shared his screen. The video took place on
9/19/21 at 3:12pm. The video has no sound. Youth A is in the doorway to the office.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 are present in the office. Youth A and Staff 2 appear to be having
a conversation. Based on Staff 2's body posture and hand movements she appears
agitated. Based on Youth A's body posture and hand movements he initially seems
calm. Youth A appears to get more agitated as they continue to talk. Staff 2 walks up
to Youth A then steps back. Youth A swings his fist and knocks over the computer
screen. Staff 1 wraps his arms around Youth A from behind him. The two fall to the
floor. There is a tussle and Youth A is seen punching staff multiple times. Staff 2
assists by laying her body on top of Youth A. At one point Staff 1 is observed in a
sitting position while Youth A is lying face down on top of him and Staff 2 is lying her
body on top of Youth A’s body. Staff 1 is able to get away from Youth A. Youth A's
body is face down on the floor while Staff 2 is still lying her body on top of him. Staff
1 is seen securing one of Youth A’s arms. A third staff who was in the doorway takes
Youth A's legs and pulls them straight so that Youth A's body is lying flat on the floor
in a prone position. Less than a minute the Staff disengage the hold.
4

The facility’s Behavior Management Philosophy and Procedures state Physical
Intervention is used when there is a clear risk of imminent harm to self, to others or
in the likelihood of significant property damage.
APPLICABLE RULE
JRM 610 Youth Restraint
General Guidance
Per Emergency CCI Rules 3(1), facility staff may only restrain a
youth to prevent serious injury to the youth, self-injury or injury
to others.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 and Staff 2 reported Youth A was restrained to prevent
harm to himself or others. The video showed Youth A was highly
escalated and swung out hitting the computer screen off the
desk while Staff 1 was standing in front of Youth A.
Technical Assistance:
The Behavior Management Philosophy and Procedures needs
to be updated to not include destruction of property as a reason
for restraint.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
When reviewing the video for the above investigation Staff 2 appears agitated as
evidenced by her body posture and hand movements. This then escalates Youth A
and he takes a swing at the computer. During this confrontation both staff remain in
the office which is a small space. Youth A stands in the open doorway. When Youth
A swings at the computer he steps into the office causing him to be restrained in a
tight spot. At first Staff 1 was under Youth A while Staff 2 laid on top of Youth A then
Staff 1 was able to get free. Staff 2 continued to lay on top of Youth A while he was
face down on the floor. A third staff takes Youth A’s legs pulling them out straight so
that Youth A’s prone body is flat on the floor. While in the restraint Youth A was
observed being restrained in a prone position with Staff 2 lying on top of Youth A.
Manager 1 was asked if this hold is something that is taught by their restraint
technique, and he stated that it appeared that staff were attempting to do the prone
restraint that was previously taught but is no longer taught due to the state
prohibiting prone restraints. He was asked if Staff 2 laying on Youth A was an
approved by the previous technique and he was stated it was not. He stated it
looked like Staff 1 was not trying to complete a restraint but rather was trying to
move Youth A.
5

Documentation from the employee files of Staff 1 and Staff 2 were reviewed. Staff 1
was hired on 12/16/20. He completed restraint training on 1/22/21 and supplemental
holds on 9/16/21. He was counseled for disrespecting a supervisor on 7/15/21.
Staff 2 was hired on 3/21/18. She completed restraint training on 1/22/21 and
supplemental holds on 9/16/21. She received discipline for attendance on 1/29/21.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the minor
child’s behavior, chronological and developmental age, size,
gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and done in a manner consistent with the resident’s treatment
plan.
ANALYSIS: Youth A is escalated by staff, restrained in an unsafe location,
and restrained in prone restraint with Staff 2 lying on top of him.
This is not a safe way to perform a restraint also, prone
restraints are not allowed in Child Caring Institutions (CCI) due
to the safety risk they impose.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (Previously cited under
Emergency Rule 1 (2)
2021C0214007, CAP approved on 3/18/21
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan it is recommended no changes
be made to the status of the license of this CCI.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted following a reported restraint of a youth at Highfields, Inc. The central allegation that staff performed a restraint due solely to property destruction was not substantiated, as the investigator concluded the restraint was initiated to prevent imminent harm. However, the investigation revealed significant additional violations: staff escalated the situation through agitated behavior, conducted the restraint in an unsafe location, and used a prohibited prone restraint technique with a staff member lying on top of the youth. Overall, the facility and its staff are culpable for unsafe restraint practices and failure to follow approved procedures.

sir_violation_level.justification: The substantiated violation involves a staff performing a restraint on a youth in a prone position with another staff lying on top of him, which is prohibited due to safety risks, and the restraint was conducted in an unsafe location. This aligns with the categorization instructions for Severe SIRs under 'Restraint and seclusion: Use of physical restraints, mechanical restraints, seclusion/isolation, or any incident suggesting excessive force or unsafe de-escalation practices.'
